a couple of years

clinical population.

catches fire?

They whispered

Did that just happen?

So I want to talk a little
bit about moral courage.

Rushworth Kidder
defines moral courage

as the capacity to act in
alignment with our values

and principles in situations
in which they are being tested.

He suggests that moral courage
requires both a commitment

to those principles
and a willingness

to endure in the face of
some risk to ourselves.

For example, to our status,
our reputation, our employment,

or our membership in
a valued social group.

Kidder argues that moral
courage can be learned,

and further suggests
that there are

several checkpoints in
the process of developing
moral courage.

The first is the ability
to assess the situation

in terms of whether moral
courage is actually required.

For example, am I
motivated by my desire

to uphold my own beliefs,
or to impose them on others?

When in the throes of outrage
about a situation that I feel

is unjust, is it
my values that are

being threatened, or only my
ego, pride, or self-interest?

The second point
that Kidder suggests

is that we, in
cultivating moral courage,

need to be able to identify
our values and the values
at stake in a situation.

Some research conducted at the
Institute for Global Ethics

suggests that there are
five core values, honesty,

responsibility, respect,
fairness, and compassion.

And that these five
values are actually

found in a range of social
groups across many cultures.

So, for example, in
my earlier story,

my assessment of the

compassion and respect

for transgender people and
for the person who spoke up.

So it was a violation of

The third capacity

What are the risks?

action has initiated

some connections

So the term white fragility,
